text: all the students on their way to the
University every morning would walk past
they a 20 foot statue of Kim jong-il and
we would all have to line up and bow to
the statue and pay our respects and then
we went on to the University and
everyone would be chatting on the way to
the University we'd all be laughing
joking and so on then as we need this
statue everyone would quiet down all
conversation would come to a halt we'd
walk up everyone had to be very quiet
very respectful hats and bags off we'd
bow walk away and then the conversation
would start up again so when I first got
there I was a very much surprised by
this and be rather intimidated you talk
about conversation I mean were you able
to communicate much with your fellow
students several of them spoke good
English most of them spoke a tiny bit of
English furthermore there were lots of
Chinese students there whose English was
much better so with my basic Korean and
their basic English we weren't
discussing the nature of existence but
we could get by with a curious about you
there was very visible split in that so
most of the people were absolutely
fascinated by life outside by my life by
life in general but then there were a
small percentage that just did not care
those who were curious though what sort
of things did they ask you about there
was a friend of mine who was an army
student who was I think around 25 to 30
who had been in the Army for 10 years
and he'd been sent to the Kim il-sung
University to get a degree in chemistry
or physics or something to that effect
and when I first got there he physically
grabbed me put me down on my bed and
said tell me everything about your
country and I said what do you want to
know
and he said well are you in the army and
I said no I'm a student he said oh but
people go to the army at what age then
and I said no we don't have military
service like you do and he was
absolutely baffled he said
people in your country they they don't
want to defend the motherland I said
well we don't have any Wars to fight at
the moment at home at least and no we
don't have national service and he said
okay well how much does a British Army
officer make where does he sleep what
what benefits is there what the people
think about him what about a US officer
and I didn't know the answer to any of
these questions but he was fascinated by
the fact that his counterparts the guy
of the same rank in the British or
American army lived a completely
different lifestyle Tim so in North
Korea you you don't buy a house it's
assigned to you by the state so they
were so intrigued by this idea that you
got your own hat you chose your house
and you paid money for your house so
they would ask me how much does a house
cost have what is rent how much is rent
overall yeah they were fascinated by the
outside world and you spoken about those
who didn't really care much about what
was going on outside those who were
quite curious but did you experience any
any kind of hostility because I mean the
state in North Korea generates an awful
lot of anti-western sort of propaganda I
mean did that filter down to students
very much so but what I saw was the
people the students they hated the
American government and there was no
apology about that they straight-up said
we detest the American government we
think they're vermin we think they're
evil imperialist dogs now the people on
the other hand they told me they had no
problem with and I was very much
surprised and I said would you not hate
the American people but detest the
American government they said well to us
the American people are merely being
misled and if they don't hate us then we
don't hate them it was very much you
liked me I like you did you ever raise
with any of the students the human
rights abuses
of the government the executions that
sort of thing no one mentioned anything
the closest I got to asking was when I
phrased the question in a particular way
so I would say you know how the
Americans have accused you of having
camps in your country where you put
political prisoners and a friend a
female friend of mine said oh yes yeah I
know what the Americans say but those
are not camps like the Japanese used to
put us in those are re-education camps
those are camps for when someone doesn't
understand the great leaders political
thought and they simply need to be
instructed which she made it sound as if
someone was simply ignorant about their
maths homework and had to have extra
classes after work
so obviously massive political
differences between you and your fellow
students but more generally cultural
differences I mean to do discuss sex to
discuss marriage yeah we discussed
everything so the sex aspect they were
very much surprised by the promiscuity
of Western youth these days when I say
promiscuity I mean purely having sex
before marriage to them was promiscuity
so they believe that you should wait
until after marriage to have sex before
that there was no point doing it so not
just in sex but in in the way they dress
they were very very Puritan so people
say North Korea's very left-wing and
obviously it is it's a communist /
socialist state but in terms of morality
I'd say they're very much right-wing
very conservative were you able to
interact with female students on campus
yes because they were students chosen to
interact with the foreign students with
an average woman on the street I
wouldn't have been able to interact
normally so there was an occasion where
I saw two girls across the street who I
found quite pretty and I was with a
friend of mine and I said it was a
Korean shall we go talk to them they
look nice let's have a chat
and he said no no no no we don't do that
here no no Alessandro don't do it and
and he led me away it's it's interesting
Alessandro used that prejudice then
female students chosen to interact with
students you were being monitored where
you would be you're being watched yes
although it wasn't as sinister as it
sounds it was the students that were put
in the foreign dormitory were there to
help us educationally and to keep an eye
on us did you feel isolated I mean
you're in this environment you had a bit
of Korea and you could communicate with
the other students but you were in a
very alien kind of environment when -
yes it was serious isolation but it made
me think also about how how North Korea
lives as a as a country I was isolated
there for four months they've now been
isolated there for 60 odd years after
four months of isolation when I got back
to China I flew to Beijing I had to
physically sit down on a bench and look
at my feet for three hours because I
could not handle the new stimuli
